children.subject: The upper-division classes will be taught by a mixture of graduate students and lecturers.  Specific instructor assignments should be available by early May.
<md>Will the upper div classes be taught by TAs or professors?</md>

Good question. The content is the same, however there are differences of class size, instructors and possible differences in format:

1) Size:  The N53 courses will be smaller (capped at around 40 students per section), however the W53 course could be quite a bit larger (often it has 250 or so students)
2)  Instructors:  The Math N53 instructors have yet to be appointed, however they will likely be PhD students or lecturers.  The W53 instructor will be Professor Thomas Scanlon (using online lectures originally developed by for Math W53 by Professor Michael Hutchings) and he will be assisted by GSIs who will lead the Tues/Thurs discussion sections, answer Piazza questions, etc. 
3) Course Formats:  The "W" courses (such as W53, W54, and W128A) were intentionally designed as online courses, and will continue to be taught fully online into the future (i.e., post the COVID-19 pandemic). Instructors worked with Digital Learning Services to convert their course content for online delivery "using specific learning design and strategies, content preparation, and technical infrastructure. Course components are organized within a bCourses template to enhance the online experience."   Most of the material for "W" courses, including video lectures, is available asynchronously, although there are some synchronous components, such as office hours and for the first time this Summer Math W53 will have 3 hours of live discussion section per week.   
On the other hand, the "N" courses are the online version of the in-person courses we have normally held every Summer.   Thus the lectures are likely to be delivered live (with Zoom recordings to be made available later).   Certain logistics will be at the discretion of the instructors who will be selected by early May, however I am told that we can expect that the instructors will: 
- Record and post lecture content online
- Structure discussion time(s)/format in ways that allow students in timezones outside of PT to participate
- Vary office hours in ways that allow students in timezones outside of PT to participate
- Make reasonable efforts to ensure that midterms/exams are accessible to students in timezones outside of PT

I learn better from prerecorded shorter lectures so looks like w53 is the choice for me. Is W53 curved? And is there specific timezones/proctoring for W53 (I'm not in PT so this matters for me). Also will math w53 satisfy reqs if i choose to double in econ or data science?

Sorry, I just saw this!  I just checked with the W53 instructor and he said:  "Math W53 will not be curved.   The quizzes and exams will be open for 24 hour periods.  However, the student should be aware that participation in the discussion sections is required; so the student should pick a convenient time for discussion."  P.S. It does not appear that Multivariable Calculus is a major requirement for either Econ or Data Science.
Whats the difference in N53 and W53?

history.content:
The Math Department is again offering a wide selection of courses this Summer in Session C (June 21st through August 13th)!   Please see below (as well as attached flyer)!

Math N1A     Calculus

Math N1B     Calculus

Math N10A   Methods of Mathematics: Calculus, Statistics & Combinatorics

Math N10B   Methods of Mathematics: Calculus, Statistics & Combinatorics

Math N16A   Analytic Geometry & Calculus

Math N16B   Analytic Geometry & Calculus

Math N32     Precalculus

Math N53     Multivariable Calculus

Math W53    Multivariable Calculus (with Professor Scanlon)

Math N54     Linear Algebra & Differential Equations
Math W54    Linear Algebra & Differential Equations (with Professor Nadler)

Math N55     Discrete Mathematics


Math 104     Introduction to Analysis

Math 110     Linear Algebra

Math 113     Introduction to Abstract Algebra

Math 115     Number Theory

Math 126     Partial Differential Equations

Math W128A Numerical Analysis (with Professor Persson)

Math 185     Complex Analysis

Course outlines for our lower-division course offerings can be found on our website at the following URL: https://math.berkeley.edu/courses/choosing/lowerdivcourses

Students who have questions about these courses can reach out to us at enrollment@math.berkeley.edu. 

With best regards,
Math Department Student Services
